content: from an article by Peter J. Boyer in the New Yorker, Apr 27 issue called The Road Ahead:Smyrna, TN vs. Detroit. "Obama's creation of the task force offered an elegant solution. He eventually put (investment banker Steven)Rattner on it, naming him senior advisor to Geithner, but his first appointment to the group, with stature equal to Rattner's, was an adviser to the United Steelworker's Union, Ron Bloom.The naming of Bloom comforted labor and signalled that a turnaround of the failed American automobile industry might be possible. It had happened in steel and Bloom had been part of it." The article goes on to explain Ron Bloom's participation in reviving the moribund steel industry that resulted in the companies shedding most of their legacy costs and turned out a leaner, more efficient industry that was soon turning a profit once again. Re- the car industry: "Bloom is not dewy-eyed about the hard-won benefits that get tossed aside at such restructurings. By the time he arrives at the table, the business has failed, and he is willing to acknowledge labor's role in the failure. His talent lies in helping to insure that labor is not asked to accept more than its fair share of sacrifice. 'The term of art that was invented by the labor unions, and that we always use, is 'equality of sacrifice,'" Psaros says. Bloom described his negotiating philosophy more graphically in a 2006 speech. "We are big believers in dentist chair bargaining," he told a gathering of insolvency lawyers and accountants. "For those of you not familiar with this approach, it is inspired by the story of the man who walks into his dentist's office, grabs the dentist by the balls, and says, 'Now, let's not hurt each other.'"... In late February, Bloom and Rattner began studying the industry and what they learned was sobering. They learned, as just one example, the GM's dealership-distribution system is hopelessly out of proportion. Honda has thirteen hundred dealerships in the US, and Toyota- GM's chief rival- has about fifteen hundred. GM has more than six thousand dealers, who are protected by state franchise laws. it will cost the company billions of dollars just to reach parity with the Japanese owned companies." These excerpts are from a very illuminating article about exactly what some of the challenges the car companies are currently facing. There are some very good people in the Obama administration and some Republicans like Bob Corker of Tennessee that are struggling hard to make things work out. Full article at: "http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2009/04/27/090427fa_fact_boyer

content: Time will tell. GM definitely must make some major alterations to their business model if they ever hope to compete on a level playing field with the imports from Japan and Korea. The place to start is the overly generous union contracts that are far out of line with those of the foreign manufacturers with U.S. assembly lines. If the UAW had not been so intransigent for so long GM might have been able to restructure much sooner.
